import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

import pandas as pd
from pandas import Series,DataFrame
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import warnings

warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')
%matplotlib inline
source.0e3e694f:
kaggle_O.Q1=kaggle_O.Q1.astype("category")
kaggle_O["Age_generation"]=kaggle_O.Q1
kaggle_O["Age_generation"]=kaggle_O["Age_generation"].replace(["35-39","40-44","45-49"],"Adults")
kaggle_O["Age_generation"]=kaggle_O["Age_generation"].replace(["18-21","22-24","25-29","30-34"],"Millennials")
kaggle_O["Age_generation"]=kaggle_O["Age_generation"].replace(["50-54","55-59","60-69","70+"],"elderly")

kaggle_O.Q3=kaggle_O.Q3.astype("category")
kaggle_O["continent"] =kaggle_O["Q3"]
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(["Malaysia","Philippines","Saudi Arabia",'Iran, Islamic Republic of...',"Viet Nam",'Republic of Korea',"India", 'Russia',"Greece","Pakistan","Japan","South Korea","Indonesia",'Hong Kong (S.A.R.)',"Turkey","Singapore","Israel","Taiwan",'Bangladesh','Thailand', 'China'],"Asia")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(["Algeria",'Tunisia',"Nigeria","Morocco","South Africa","Egypt","Kenya"],"Africa")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(['Austria',"Belgium","Romania",'Denmark','France','Germany','Netherlands','Italy','Ireland',"Ukraine",'Portugal',"Switzerland","Chile","Hungary","Norway","Belarus","Sweden","United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland","Poland","Spain","Czech Republic"],"Europe")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(["United States of America","Mexico","Canada"],"North America")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(["Brazil","Argentina","Colombia",'Peru'],"South America")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(['Australia',"New Zealand"],"'Australia")
kaggle_O["continent"]= kaggle_O["continent"].replace(["Other"],"Not classified")

kaggle_O.Q5=kaggle_O.Q5.astype("category")
kaggle_O["Employed"]=kaggle_O["Q5"]
kaggle_O["Employed"]=kaggle_O["Employed"].replace(["Data Scientist","Software Engineer","Other","Data Analyst","Research Scientist",
                                               "Business Analyst","Product/Project Manager","Data Engineer","Statistician",
                                               "DBA/Database Engineer"],"Employed")

kaggle_O.Q4=kaggle_O.Q4.astype("category")
kaggle_O["Educated"]=kaggle_O["Q4"]
kaggle_O["Educated"]=kaggle_O["Educated"].replace(["Master’s degree","Bachelor’s degree","Doctoral degree","Professional degree "],"Educated")
source.75563973:
plt.figure(figsize=(10,8))
ax1=sns.countplot(y="Q2",data=kaggle, order=kaggle["Q2"].value_counts().index)
plt.title('Figure(1):Gender Distribution of Youth kaggle participants in 2019')
plt.xlabel("Percentage")
plt.ylabel('Gender')

for p in ax1.patches:
    ax1.text(p.get_width()+.3, p.get_y()+.38, str(round((p.get_width()/len(kaggle))*100, 2))+'%')

source.58d1a51f:
Q9         = kaggle.loc[:,"Q9_Part_1":"Q9_Part_8"].apply(lambda x: x.count()).to_frame()
Q9.index   = (["Analyze and understand data to influence product or business decisions",
               "Build and/or run the data infrastructure that my business uses for storing analyzing, and operationalizing data",
               "Build prototypes to explore applying machine learning to new areas',",
                "Build and/or run a machine learning service that operationally improves my product or workflows",
                "Experimentation and iteration to improve existing ML models",
                "Do research that advances the state of the art of machine learning",
                "None of these activities are an important part of my role at work","Other"])
Q9.columns = ["Frequency"]
Q9.sort_values(by="Frequency",ascending=False,inplace=True)
print(Q9)

Q9.plot.barh(width=0.9,figsize=(12, 13))
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
plt.title('Figure(10): Top ML Activities that Youth kaggle participant adapt in their work ')
plt.show()

kaggle["compensation"]=kaggle["Q10"]
kaggle["compensation"]=kaggle["compensation"].replace(["$0-999"],"0-1k")
kaggle["compensation"]=kaggle["compensation"].replace(["1,000-1,999","2,000-2,999","3,000-3,999","4,000-4,999","5,000-7,499",
                                                      "7,500-9,999","8,000-8,999","9,000-9,999"],"1k-10k")

kaggle["compensation"]=kaggle["compensation"].replace(["10,000-14,999","15,000-19,999","20,000-24,999","25,000-29,999","30,000-39,999",
                                                       "40,000-49,999","50,000-59,999","60,000-69,999","70,000-79,999","80,000-89,999","90,000-99,999"],"1k-10k")

kaggle["compensation"]=kaggle["compensation"].replace(["100,000-124,999","125,000-149,999","150,000-199,999","200,000-249,999"
                                                       ,"250,000-299,999","300,000-500,000","> $500,000"],"+100k")

Q25.plot.barh(width=0.9,figsize=(12, 8))
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()
plt.title('Figure(29):Automated Machine Learning')
plt.show()

source.d0a35544:
Kaggle’s State of Machine Learning and Data Science 2019 survey has about 19,717 respondents from 171 countries a round the world, the country which has less than 50 respondents was grouped to "Others" which later named as "Not classified". The respondent were found through kaggle channels, email list, discussion forums and social media channels from October 8th to October 28th in 2019, However this reports only focused on millennial respondent whose their ages are from 18-34 years.

Multiple choice multiple response questions were split into multiple columns to give the respondent the ability to select more than one option, so for many charts where the total percentage is above 100% All monetary amounts captured in the report are in USD.
source.0fabaacc: Coursera is coming on the top platforms that kaggle millennial are using for taking data science courses, and you can give the reason for this to their huge, diversity and the quality of courses they have in addition to possibility to apply of financial Aids

source.f5130531:
Out of 19,717 usable respondents from 171 countries, this exclusive summary will focus on **(69.43%) who's their ages are from 18-34 years** or Millennial.

The analysis of this report will based on EDA to explore the main characteristics of Millennial in kaggle community such as **demographic status**, **Working environment** , we will also put highlight on their **learning path**, **technology adapted** their **weakness or skill shortage** and many other things. we also will identify any differences for these characteristic based on gender and continent.

In general we see that kaggle community of millennial are mostly male and have university degree, they having little experience in data science fields and consider kaggle their favorite platforms for learning data science, you will see that North America has the highest pay and most spending on machine learning and cloud computing products.
source.e60637aa:
Waww, we have high proportions of educated millennial in kaggle community for both male female, about (88%) of millennial has university degree and about (52%) has advanced university degree especially the master degree.
The result shouldn't be surprising since you should have knowledge of advanced statistics, math and programming to able to compete and stand out among others in kaggle competitions

source.fe492d09:
The third annual State of Machine Learning and Data Science 2019 survey gathered some insight about the kaggle community that covers their demographics, working inviroment, learning path and techology adapted.

Many stories on kaggle community can be told but our analysis put the highlight on largest and most sensetive kaggle community group of millennial who's their ages from 18-34 years.

The main conclusion can be said on this group of kaggle community is it dominated by male, highly educated working at companies of all sizes that are still have little experience in coding and adapting machine learning technology at their work.
source.7308677f: It seems like the company is not interested in spending much money on ML and/or cloud computing products, about (37%) of these companies spend less than 1000$ in the past 5 years, (19.2%) has not spent at all
source.8e0de4c0:
The analysis indicates that the companies are still not adapting machine learning in their production phases in wide range, only (11.18%) of these companies is adapting machine learning in their productions for more than two years. and (9.8%) didn't use it at all.
Now lets dive deep in out analysis to get more insight. * It seem like big companies is more willing to adapt ML in the production phase more than small companies, and you can give this to their financial ability for this transition and the awareness of Ml importance in solving their problems and increase their profits. * And the thing that should be obvious that when you have large data science team then you looking for taking machine learning into the next level of production.
source.d35ce183: About (58%) of kaggle millennials are recommnded aspiring data scientist to learn python, it's flexibility, ease to use, open source and well supporting make it number one programming for data scientist.
source.cecdf9dc: Clearly there is a significant gender gap between male and female, where (80.66%) of millennial are males, only (17.68%) of millennial are female, and thus we have to understand reasons behind this low participation and much working into females engage into kaggle community

source.77e18b2d: In general millennial tend to not have the highest yearly compensation rate for both male and female, and can't be expect otherwise because we are talking about young people in their career beginning and has low working experience.
source.58b83c31:
## Main Findings
* Most of Millennial in kaggle community are Males. * Half of Millennial are coming from Asia. * More than (80%) of Millennial has university degree and more than (50%) has advanced university degree. * Most of Millennial work at either small or very large organizations. * Half of Millennial have less than 2 years of experience in writing codes. * Millennial in North America has the highest compensation and Asia has the lowest. * North America is most continent spending on machine learning and cloud computing products. * Jupyter is most common analytics tool among all other IDE for kaggle community of millennial. * Python is most common programming language for data science for kaggle community of millennial. * Kaggle is millennial favorites media for data science and coursera is the best teaching platform. * Millennial are most Appling simple ML method such as linear and logistic regression, Decision trees and random forest in their regular work using sicit_learn, their favorite ML package. * Millennial are not familiar with cloud computing, big data/analytics and machine learning products.
source.5b8d442a: This section put highlight on products that few of millennials in kaggle community are familiar with, such as cloud computing products, Big data / analytics products, Machine Learning products and Automated machine learning tools
